Every movement in Riker hits a set of muscles.  There are primary muscles hit and secondary muscles hit.

For example, the primary muscles hit with bench press are: the upper and lower chest muscles.  The secondary muscles hit are: the three heads of the tricep muscle group.

Riker distributes 80% of the total weight lifted and reps of a set to the primary muscles hit, and distributes the remaining 20% to the secondary muscles hit.

If there are multiple primary muscles and multiple secondary muscles hit, the assigned weight and reps are distributed across them evenly.

So if you do a set of 10 reps of 135 lbs on bench press, the total weight lifted is: 1,350 lbs.  80% of that weight (1,080 lbs) and 80% of the reps (8 reps) are assigned to the primary muscles; the upper and lower chest.  Since there are 2 primary muscles hit, they are each assigned 540 lbs and 4 reps.  The secondary muscles hit are assigned 20% of the total weight lifted and reps (270 lbs and 2 reps).  Since there are 3 secondary muscles hit (medial, lateral and long heads of the tricep), they are each assigned 90 lbs and 0.67 reps.

Google Fit lets you control your fitness data from multiple apps and devices.

By connecting Google Fit and Riker, you can integrate your Riker workouts and body weight measurements to Google Fit.

Whether or not to track the time component (hour, minute and second) of when the set was recorded.

From here you can drill into all of your data records.
Sets
Import / Export

Riker supports importing and exporting of your set data.

After exporting, you\'ll be given the option to share the CSV file (e.g., you can email it to yourself or save it to Google Drive).  Tap the Show Files button to see all your existing export files.

Tap Import to choose a set data file to import into Riker.

Riker supports importing and exporting of your body measurement log data.

After exporting, you\'ll be given the option to share the CSV file (e.g., you can email it to yourself or save it to Google Drive).  Tap the Show Files button to see all your existing export files.

Tap Import to choose a body log data file to import into Riker.
To Failure
Did you do as many reps as possible? Or did you have more in you? If you had more reps in you, uncheck this.
Negatives

Slowly loading the weight in the \'down\' position of a movement, with a partner helping to bring the weight to the starting position.
Also known as eccentric training.
Real Time

If you\'re using Riker to record your sets as you\'re actually working out, keep this checked, and Riker will record the timestamps of your sets automatically.
If you\'re using Riker to record your sets that you previously wrote down in a journal (you\'re digitizing your old data), then uncheck this box so you can manually enter the date.
Ignore time of day
Ignore the hour, minute and seconds part of the log date. Instead, just save the date.
Riker Account Benefits

There are several benefits to having a Riker Account subscription:

Syncable to all your devices

With a Riker account, your data is syncable to all your devices, including:

  •  All your Android devices (including tablets)
  •  iPhones and iPads
  •  Web

Safe storage of your data

With a Riker account, your data is safely and securely stored on our servers, making it accessible to all of your devices.

Web access

With a Riker account, you\'ll be able to access your data from the Riker web site.
Riker without an Account?

Yes. 100% of Riker\'s features are available in the free phone and tablet apps.

Without an account subscription, the app will store all of your data locally to your device. The risk is if you lose your device, or you accidentally uninstall Riker, you would lose all your data (unless you back it up). Without a subscription, there is no Riker web access.

That said, Riker\'s export / import functionality can be used to manually backup your data, or transfer it to another device.
After the 90-day trial, you\'ll have 2 choices for continuing with Riker:
Enroll in a Riker subscription and continue to enjoy the benefits of having a Riker account. The cost is __PRICE__ per year.

100% of Riker\'s features are available in the free phone and tablet apps. Without an account subscription, the app will store all of your data locally to your device. The risk is if you lose your device, or you accidentally uninstall Riker, you would lose all your data (unless you back it up). Without a subscription, there is no Riker web access.

That said, Riker\'s export / import functionality can be used to manually backup your data, or transfer it to another device.

Weight Lifted

The Weight Lifted metric is the total amount of weight lifted for a set. It is the number of reps multiplied by the weight used.

For example, if you bench pressed 135 lbs for 10 reps, the weight lifted = 1,350 lbs.

Riker uses this metric as an objective, quantative measure associated with your strength. Several charts are provided for this metric.
Total Weight Lifted
Average per Set
Distribution
Distribution / Time
Total Weight Lifted
Average per Set
Weight Lifted Distribution

These timeline charts illustrate your strength over time.

As you get stronger and are able to lift more weight, you should see the lines trending upwards over time.

Each point on a line represents the total, aggregate weight lifted for that point in time. If you have a filter set to aggregate by week, month, etc., points represent the total weight lifted over the selected time period.

For example, if your quadriceps lifted a grand total of 10,000 lbs over a contiguous 5-day period, and you have a filter set to aggregate by week, then the data point will display at 10,000 lbs.
Total Weight Lifted by Muscle Group
The following charts detail your total weight lifted across the individual muscles of your muscle groups, over time.
Total Weight Lifted by Movement Variant
The following timeline charts detail your total weight lifted across the different movement variants, over time.
This chart illustrates the sum total of all your weight lifted, for all movements, over time.
This chart illustrates how the sum total of all your weight lifted, for all movements, distributes between your upper and lower body, over time.
This chart illustrates how the sum total of all your weight lifted, for all movements, distributes across all your major muscle groups, over time.
This chart illustrates how the sum total of all your weight lifted, for movements that hit upper body muscles, distributes across all your upper body muscle groups, over time.
This chart illustrates how the sum total of all your weight lifted, for movements that hit the shoulders, distributes across your individual shoulder muscles, over time.

These timeline charts illustrate your strength per set over time.

As you get stronger and are able to lift more weight, you should see the lines trending upwards over time.

Each point on a line represents the average weight lifted per set for that point in time. For example, if you did 3 sets of curls:

  1.  10 reps of 95 lbs,
  2.  8 reps of 90 lbs and
  3.  8 reps of 80 lbs
your total weight lifted would be: 2,310 lbs. Your average per set would be: 770 lbs.

If you have a filter set to aggregate by week, month, etc., points represent the average weight lifted per set over the selected time period.

These pie charts show where your strength is distributed. There are charts to show how your strength is distributed across your muscle groups and movement variants.
They are helpful for shedding light on areas of your strength training that you may neglect or overwork.
For example, if you don\'t do enough lower body training, that would show in the Total Weight Lifted - Body Segments pie chart. The lower body slice would be disproportionately smaller than the upper body slice.
Weight Lifted Distribution by Muscle Group
The following pie charts detail how your total weight lifted distributes across the individual muscles of your muscle groups.
Weight Lifted Distribution by Movement Variant
The following pie charts detail how your total weight lifted distributes across the different movement variants.

These timeline charts illustrate where your strength is distributed over time.

For example, if over time you begin to neglect lower body training, you will see the lower body line trend downwards over time, and the upper body line trend upwards.

Reps

The Reps metric is simply the number of reps done for a set (regardless of the weight used).
Several charts are provided for this metric.
Total Reps
Average per Set
Distribution
Distribution / Time
Total Reps
Average per Set
Reps Distribution

If you\'re a beginner, as you get stronger and your stamina increases, you should see the lines trending upwards over time. Or, if you normally prefer doing high-rep sets, but decide to change to start doing heavier weight with less reps, you should see the lines trending downwards over time.
Each point on a line represents the sum total rep count for that point in time. If you have a filter set to aggregate by week, month, etc., points represent the aggregate rep count over the selected time period.
For example, if your shoulders did a grand total of 175 reps over a contiguous 3-day period, and you have a filter set to aggregate by week, then the data point will display at 175 reps.
Total Reps by Muscle Group
The following charts detail your total reps across the individual muscles of your muscle groups, over time.
Total Reps by Movement Variant
The following timeline charts detail your total reps across the different movement variants, over time.
This chart illustrates the sum total of all your reps, for all movements, over time.

These timeline charts illustrate your average rep count over time.
If you\'re a beginner, as you get stronger and your stamina increases, you should see the lines trending upwards over time. Or, if you normally prefer doing high-rep sets, but decide to change to start doing heavier weight with less reps, you should see the lines trending downwards over time.
Each point on a line represents the sum total rep count for that point in time. If you have a filter set to aggregate by week, month, etc., points represent the average rep count over the selected time period.
Each point on a line represents the average rep count per set for that point in time. For example, if you did 3 sets of calf raises
  1. 10 reps of 295 lbs
  2. 8 reps of 275 lbs
  3. 8 reps of 265 lbs
your total rep count would be: 26. Your average per set would be: 8.7.
If you have a filter set to aggregate by week, month, etc., points represent the average rep count per set over the selected time period.

These pie charts enable you to make comparisons with the Reps metric across time periods.
They are helpful for spotting training inconsistencies.
For example, if you tend to do very high rep sets for your shoulder movements, but then do very low-rep movements for all your chest movements, that would show in the Total Reps - Muscle Groups pie chart. The shoulders slice would be disproportionately larger than the chest slice.

Rest Time

The Rest Time metric is the amount of rest time spent between sets of the same movement and variant.
For example, if you do 3 sets of machine shoulder press, this metric captures your rest time between sets 1 and 2, and sets 2 and 3.
Time spent between sets when switching to a new movement or variant is not counted.
Total Rest Time
Average per Set
Distribution
Distribution / Time
Total Rest Time
Average per Set
Rest Time Distribution

The aggregate timeline charts illustrate your rest time spent between sets over time.
Each point on a line represents the total time spent between sets for that point in time. If you have a filter set to aggregate by week, month, etc., points represent the aggregate time spent between sets over the selected time period.
For example, if you spent a grand total of 20 minutes resting between sets of deadlifts over a contiguous 3-day period, and you have a filter set to aggregate by week, then the data point will display at 20 minutes.

These timeline charts illustrate your average rest time spent between sets over time.
If you change your workout style over time in terms of how long of a rest you take between sets, the data lines will trend accordingly.
Each point on a line represents the average time between sets for that point in time. If you have a filter set to aggregate by week, month, etc., points represent the average time spent between sets over the selected time period.
Each point on a line represents the average time spent between sets for that point in time. For example, if you did 3 sets of Arnold presses, and between sets (1) and (2) you rested for 45 seconds, and between sets (2) and (3) you rested for 54 seconds, your total time between sets would be: 99 seconds. Your average per set would be: 49.5 seconds.\n\nIf you have a filter set to aggregate by week, month, etc., points represent the average time spent between sets over the selected time period.

These pie charts show how your time spent between sets is distributed. There are charts to show how your time between sets are distributed across your muscle groups and movement variants.
They are helpful for spotting training inconsistencies.
For example, if you tend to take long rest periods between chest movement sets, but then have very short rest periods between back movement sets, that would show in the Total Time Spent Between Sets - Upper Body Muscle Groups pie chart. The chest slice would be disproportionately larger than the back slice.

These timeline charts illustrate how your time spent between sets is distributed over time.
For example, if over time you increase your rest time between sets for upper body training, or shorten your rest time for lower body training, you will see the upper body line trend upwards over time, and the upper body line trend downwards.
